description: From Middle English soren, from Old French essorer (“to fly up, soar”), from Vulgar Latin *exaurare (“to rise into the air”), from Latin ex (“out”) + aura (“the air, a breeze”), from Ancient Greek αὔρα (aúra, “breath”). Compare aura, and exhale.

examples: this apparent soar of the hooded falcon

verbs.description: soar (third-person singular simple present soars, present participle soaring, simple past and past participle soared)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To fly high with little effort, like a bird.
To mount upward on wings, or as on wings, especially by gliding while employing rising air currents.
To remain aloft by means of a glider or other unpowered aircraft.
To rise, especially rapidly or unusually high.
examples: The pump prices soared into new heights as the strike continued.

entries.meaning: (figuratively) To rise in thought, spirits, or imagination; to be exalted in mood.
